study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between participation in a brief mindfulness program (PCbMP) and changes in diurnal cortisol levels in veterans with PTSD.
results_summary: Veterans completing 4 mindfulness sessions showed significant reductions in cortisol awakening response and changes in cortisol area under the curve compared to the control group, indicating a beneficial physiological impact of PCbMP.
population_specificity: Veterans (mean age 48±16 years, 90% men) with PTSD referred through VA primary care providers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a standardized mindfulness meditation program (MBSR) on chronic pain, physical and mental function, pain acceptance, and health-related quality of life.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in vitality (primary outcome), general anxiety, depression, mental quality of life, pain control, and pain acceptance, with small nonsignificant effects on pain measures. Effects remained stable at the 6-month follow-up.
population_specificity: 109 patients with nonspecific chronic pain.
study_duration: Duration of MBSR course not specified, but follow-up was at 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a mantram repetition program (MRP) increased mindful attention in veterans with PTSD and whether this mediated improvements in PTSD symptoms and psychological well-being.
results_summary: The study found that MRP significantly increased mindful attention compared to treatment as usual (TAU), and these gains mediated reductions in PTSD symptoms, depression, and improvements in psychological well-being. Frequency of mantram repetition practice was linked to increased mindful attention.
population_specificity: Veterans with PTSD from military-related trauma recruited from a Veterans Affairs outpatient PTSD clinic.
effective_dosage: Not specified (frequency of mantram repetition practice was measured via wrist-worn counters and daily logs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) is superior to psycho-educative coaching in reducing obsessive-compulsive symptoms and improving associated parameters in OCD patients with no or partial response to CBT.
results_summary: The study hypothesized that MBCT would outperform the active control (OCD-EP) in reducing OCD symptoms (measured by Y-BOCS) post-intervention and at 6- and 12-month follow-ups, with secondary benefits in depressive symptoms, quality of life, metacognitive beliefs, self-compassion, mindful awareness, and approach-avoidance tendencies. Results were not provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: 128 patients with primary OCD diagnosis (DSM-IV) and no/partial response to CBT, recruited from in-/outpatient services, online forums, and media.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of mindfulness-based interventions, particularly meditation, in improving psychological functioning in individuals with borderline personality disorder (BPD).
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness-based interventions led to improvements in impulsivity, emotional irregularity, and relationship instability in individuals with BPD, with some no longer meeting diagnostic criteria after treatment. Neuroscientific findings also indicated increased gray matter in key brain areas.
population_specificity: Individuals diagnosed with borderline personality disorder (BPD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a multimodal resilience training program, including mindfulness-based stress reduction, was feasible and acceptable for ICU nurses and could improve psychological outcomes.
results_summary: The program was feasible and acceptable, with both treatment and control groups showing a significant decrease in PTSD symptom scores, though the study did not isolate mindfulness's specific effects.
population_specificity: ICU nurses
effective_dosage: Not specified (part of a multimodal intervention)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of mindfulness-based cancer recovery (MBCR) and supportive-expressive group therapy (SET) on telomere length and psychological outcomes in distressed breast cancer survivors.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in telomere length between MBCR and SET groups, but a trend toward telomere maintenance in the combined intervention group compared to controls. No associations were found between changes in telomere length and mood or stress scores.
population_specificity: Distressed breast cancer survivors (stage I-III) who had completed treatment at least 3 months prior.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the impact of mindfulness-based treatment (M) with cognitive-behavioral therapy for pain (CBT-P) and arthritis education (E) on daily pain- and stress-related outcomes in adults with rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
results_summary: Mindfulness (M) showed greater reductions in daily pain-related catastrophizing, morning disability, fatigue, and stress-related anxious affect compared to CBT-P and E. CBT-P had less pronounced declines in daily pain-related perceived control than M and E.
population_specificity: Adults with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) (n=143).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether integrating mindfulness training into the Strengthening Families Program (SFP 10-14) could enhance parenting skills and reduce youth problem behaviors compared to the standard program and a minimal-treatment control.
results_summary: The Mindfulness-Enhanced Strengthening Families Program (MSFP) was as effective as standard SFP 10-14 in improving parenting dimensions and parent-youth relationships, with some areas showing enhanced and sustained effects, particularly for fathers. The results, while not uniformly strong, suggest mindfulness activities may uniquely benefit parent training.
population_specificity: 432 families, including 31% racial/ethnic minority parents and youth aged 10-14.
study_duration: Postintervention and 1-year follow-up (exact intervention duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify predictors for health behavior change, including mindfulness practice, after an integrative medicine inpatient program.
results_summary: The study found short- and long-term increases in the practice frequency of relaxation techniques, including mindfulness meditation, with self-efficacy and health locus of control being significant predictors of adherence.
population_specificity: German internal medicine patients (N=2,486; 80% female; mean age 53.9±14.3 years).
study_duration: 14-day inpatient program, with follow-ups at 3, 6, and 12 months post-discharge.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of non-pharmacological interventions, including mindfulness (a third-wave CBT), for somatoform disorders and medically unexplained physical symptoms (MUPS) in adults.
results_summary: Mindfulness, as part of psychological therapies, showed a small to medium reduction in symptom severity compared to usual care or waiting lists, but no clear difference compared to enhanced care. The overall quality of evidence was low to moderate.
population_specificity: Adults primarily diagnosed with somatoform disorders or MUPS, recruited from healthcare settings and the open population.
effective_dosage: Not specified (mindfulness was part of broader psychological therapies with sessions ranging from 1 to 13 over one day to nine months).
study_duration: Varied from one day to nine months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether relationships among inpatient medical teams, including mindfulness, were associated with patient outcomes like length of stay and complication rates.
results_summary: Teams with higher relationship scores, including trust and mindfulness, had significantly lower unnecessary length of stay and complication rates. Mindfulness was linked to improved patient outcomes in hospital settings.
population_specificity: Inpatient medical teams and their patients at Audie L. Murphy Veterans Affairs Hospital and University Hospital in San Antonio, Texas.
study_duration: Observations occurred over 2- to 4-week periods from September 2008 through June 2011.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of an all-outdoors vocational rehabilitation program versus a mainly indoors program on stress-related symptoms, including mindfulness, in individuals on long-term sick leave.
results_summary: Both interventions showed significant within-group improvements in mindfulness and other outcomes, with small to large effect sizes, but minimal differences between the outdoor and indoor settings. The results suggest comparable efficacy between the two approaches.
population_specificity: Individuals on long-term sick leave due to sustained stress-related symptoms.
study_duration: 6 months (with assessments at baseline, 3 months, and 6 months)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review how meditation could comfort terminally ill patients by examining its effects on physical health, emotional health, and self-awareness.
results_summary: The review found limited research on meditation's effects on terminally ill patients, with most studies focusing on non-terminally ill patients who reacted positively. Key areas like physical health, mental health, and self-awareness in terminally ill patients remain under-researched.
population_specificity: Terminally ill patients (TIPs) and non-terminally ill patients (NTIPs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of flotation tank treatment on psychological and physiological variables, including mindfulness, in healthy participants.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in stress, depression, anxiety, and worst pain, along with increased optimism and sleep quality for the flotation-REST group. A significant correlation was observed between mindfulness in daily life and altered states of consciousness during flotation.
population_specificity: Healthy participants (65 individuals: 14 men, 51 women) from a cooperative-health project initiated by their companies.
effective_dosage: Twelve flotation sessions over seven weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the pharmaco-toxicological profile of opioid-treated chronic low back pain (CLBP) patients and identify potential areas for care optimization.
results_summary: The study found high medication burden and substance misuse among opioid-treated CLBP patients, with 15 participants testing positive for illicit drugs or unprescribed medications. No findings related to Mindfulness were reported.
population_specificity: Chronic low back pain patients prescribed ≥ 30 mg/d of morphine-equivalent dose (MED) for ≥3 months (N = 35, 80% female, average age 51.8 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT) as a public mental health intervention for adults with mild to moderate depressive symptoms in a natural setting.
results_summary: MBCT significantly reduced depression, anxiety, and experiential avoidance while improving mindfulness and emotional/psychological mental health compared to the control group, with sustained effects at a 3-month follow-up. The MBCT group had a higher likelihood of clinically significant improvement in depressive symptoms.
population_specificity: Adults with mild to moderate depressive symptomatology recruited from the general population.
study_duration: Duration of intervention not explicitly stated in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the feasibility of a mindfulness intervention to reduce antenatal depression, anxiety, and stress through a pilot study involving both a non-randomised trial and a randomised controlled trial.
results_summary: The study found significant within-group improvements in depression and anxiety in the non-randomised trial, and in anxiety and mindfulness in the RCT intervention arm, but no between-group differences compared to the control. Recruitment challenges and participant retention were noted, with over a third of participants scoring above clinical cut-offs for depression and anxiety.
population_specificity: Pregnant women, including those at risk of mental health problems (selected population) and a universal population.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mindfulness-based cognitive therapy self-help (MBCT-SH) for students compared to a wait-list control group.
results_summary: MBCT-SH showed significant improvements in depression, anxiety, stress, life satisfaction, mindfulness, and self-compassion, with effect sizes ranging from small to large. Engagement was high, with low dropout rates, suggesting MBCT-SH is a promising low-cost intervention.
population_specificity: University students
effective_dosage: Eight-week program with mindfulness practice a median of two to three times per week

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an abridged mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) intervention could improve wellness measures (stress, resilience, self-compassion) in first-year medical students.
results_summary: The MBSR intervention significantly improved self-compassion (SCS) at 8 weeks and 6 months, reduced perceived stress (PSS) at 8 weeks (but not at 6 months), and showed no significant change in resilience (RS), though RS correlated with SCS and PSS.
population_specificity: First-year medical students (n=58).
effective_dosage: 75 minutes of weekly class time, suggested home meditation, and a half-day retreat in the last week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of mindfulness-based stress reduction as a nonpharmacologic intervention for cancer-related fatigue.
results_summary: The abstract suggests mindfulness-based stress reduction appears promising for managing cancer-related fatigue but lacks convincing evidence compared to other interventions like physical activity and cognitive-behavioral therapy.
population_specificity: Cancer patients and survivors experiencing fatigue.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of metacognitive detached mindfulness therapy and stress management training on hypertension and symptoms of depression and anxiety versus a control condition.
results_summary: Both psychotherapeutic interventions (mindfulness and stress management) led to greater reductions in blood pressure and symptoms of depression and anxiety compared to the control group, with effects sustained at an 8-week follow-up.
population_specificity: 45 female patients with a mean age of 36.49 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a mindfulness-based intervention (MBI) versus psycho-oncological telephone consultation on health-related quality of life (HRQoL), depression, anxiety, and fatigue in hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) survivors.
results_summary: MBI improved HRQoL and reduced depression and anxiety post-intervention with moderate effect sizes (Cohen's d 0.6-0.7), though follow-up benefits were modest. The intervention showed broad feasibility, acceptance, and adherence among participants.
population_specificity: Medically stable HSCT survivors who completed transplantation ≥6 months prior.
effective_dosage: Structured 8-week mindfulness training program (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether baseline dispositional mindfulness predicts changes in waking salivary cortisol levels and well-being among cancer survivors.
results_summary: Cancer survivors with lower baseline mindfulness showed increased waking cortisol over time, while those with higher mindfulness had stable cortisol levels. Increased cortisol was associated with decreased well-being.
population_specificity: Cancer survivors

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of an 8-week mindfulness stress management program on depression, anxiety, stress, and quality of life in reproductive-age women with PCOS.
results_summary: The intervention group showed statistically significant reductions in stress, depressive and anxiety symptoms, and salivary cortisol levels, along with improved life satisfaction and quality of life, with no significant placebo effect.
population_specificity: Reproductive-age women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the benefits and acceptability of two mindfulness-based interventions (MBCT and MMP) for improving distress, quality of life, and mindfulness in women with breast and gynecologic cancer.
results_summary: Both interventions showed medium to large improvements in distress, quality of life, and mindfulness, with no significant differences between the two programs. Participants perceived both as beneficial and acceptable.
population_specificity: Women with breast and gynecologic cancer.
effective_dosage: MBCT: 22 contact hours over 8 weeks; MMP: 9 contact hours over 6 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mind-body practices, including mindfulness, for patients with diagnosed cardiac disease.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found moderate to large effect sizes for improvements in physical and mental quality of life, depression, anxiety, and blood pressure, though the overall quality of the included studies was low.
population_specificity: Patients with diagnosed cardiac disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the associations between formal and informal mindfulness home practice and treatment outcomes in Mindfulness-based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) for preventing depression relapse.
results_summary: The study found a significant positive association between formal home practice duration and outcome, with participants practicing formally at least 3 days per week being nearly half as likely to relapse. No significant association was found between informal practice and outcome, possibly due to measurement challenges.
population_specificity: Ninety-nine participants with a history of Major Depression randomized to MBCT in a multi-centre trial.
effective_dosage: Formal home practice on at least 3 days per week (specific duration not quantified).
study_duration: 7 treatment weeks, with follow-up assessments up to 12 months post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a combined mental (focused attention meditation) and physical (aerobic exercise) training intervention (MAP Training) on aerobic fitness, depression, and anxiety symptoms in a high-risk population.
results_summary: Preliminary data showed that MAP Training improved aerobic fitness and reduced symptoms of depression and anxiety in participants, with no similar improvements observed in a control group. The study could not confirm whether new neuron generation in the hippocampus was affected by the intervention.
population_specificity: Recently homeless young mothers with histories of physical/sexual abuse, addiction, and depression.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of mental training (20min sitting meditation, 10min walking meditation) followed by 30 minutes of moderate-intensity aerobic exercise, 2 sessions per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of the attention training technique (ATT) and a mindfulness-based task on focus of attention and anxiety reduction.
results_summary: The mindfulness-based task increased self-focused attention and reduced anxiety, while ATT increased external focus of attention and also reduced anxiety. Changes in self-focused attention were linked to anxiety reduction differently for each intervention.
population_specificity: Nonclinical participants

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT) on suicidal ideation in patients with residual depressive symptoms and whether this effect was mediated by changes in depression severity, worry, rumination, or mindfulness.
results_summary: MBCT significantly reduced suicidal ideation in the treatment group compared to the control group, an effect that remained significant even after accounting for changes in depression, worry, rumination, and mindfulness. The reduction in suicidal ideation was partially mediated by decreased worry.
population_specificity: Patients with residual depressive symptoms

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a mindfulness-based intervention (Mindful Family Stress Reduction) on attentional self-regulation in school-age youths using the Attention Network Task (ANT).
results_summary: The study found significant, medium-size improvements in attentional self-regulation among youths who participated in the mindfulness-based intervention compared to the wait-list control group. The results suggest mindfulness training may enhance attention in children.
population_specificity: School-age youths and their parents (41 parent-child dyads).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Alliance-focused training (AFT) in enhancing therapists' skills for recognizing and managing alliance ruptures through mindfulness and other techniques.
results_summary: The study found that AFT, incorporating mindfulness training, videotape analysis, and role-plays, was useful for trainees in improving therapeutic skills like self-awareness and interpersonal sensitivity. Feedback from trainees indicated the techniques were beneficial, though challenges in implementation were noted.
population_specificity: Therapists in training (trainees in the program).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the therapeutic value of structured Tai Chi training, which incorporates mindfulness, for improving coordination, balance, fatigue, and depression in mildly disabled MS patients.
results_summary: The Tai Chi group showed significant improvements in balance, coordination, and depression, with stable fatigue levels, while the comparison group experienced worsened fatigue. Life satisfaction also improved in the Tai Chi group.
population_specificity: 32 mildly disabled MS patients (EDSS < 5).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility, acceptability, and efficacy of a modified mindfulness-based stress reduction program (MBSR-tics) for treating Tourette Syndrome (TS) and Chronic Tic Disorder (CTD) in individuals aged 16 and older.
results_summary: MBSR-tics was found feasible and acceptable, significantly improving tic severity and impairment, with 58.8% of subjects responding to treatment. Gains were maintained at one-month follow-up, and improvements correlated with increased mindfulness.
population_specificity: Individuals aged 16-67 with Tourette Syndrome or Chronic Tic Disorder.
effective_dosage: 8 weekly 2-hour classes and one 4-hour retreat in the fifth or sixth week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of mindfulness meditation (specifically MBSR and MBTI) for treating chronic insomnia compared to a self-monitoring condition.
results_summary: Mindfulness meditation (MBSR and MBTI) significantly reduced total wake time, pre-sleep arousal, and insomnia severity compared to self-monitoring, with MBTI showing superior long-term effects on insomnia severity at follow-up. Both interventions sustained remission and response rates, with MBTI achieving higher rates at 6 months.
population_specificity: Fifty-four adults with chronic insomnia.
study_duration: Eight weeks, with follow-up assessments at 3 and 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) versus a brief structured group psychoeducation intervention in reducing subsyndromal depressive symptoms and improving cognitive performance in bipolar disorder patients.
results_summary: The study hypothesized that MBCT would be more effective than psychoeducation in reducing depressive symptoms and improving cognitive performance, with an expected increase in BDNF levels post-intervention. Results were not explicitly stated in the abstract, but the trial design suggests a rigorous comparison.
population_specificity: Patients with bipolar disorder and subclinical or mild depressive symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review treatment options, including mindfulness-based therapy, for depression in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: The abstract mentions mindfulness-based therapy as one of several treatment options reviewed for MS-related depression, but it does not provide specific findings on its effectiveness compared to other therapies.
population_specificity: Patients with multiple sclerosis (MS) experiencing depression.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) in reducing cancer-related fatigue (CRF) and associated symptoms in cancer survivors.
results_summary: The MBSR group showed large post-intervention reductions in fatigue interference, fatigue severity, depression, and sleep disturbance, with improvements maintained or strengthened at follow-up. High adherence and participant-reported home practice were noted.
population_specificity: 35 cancer survivors with clinically significant CRF.
effective_dosage: 7-week MBSR-based intervention (mindfulness meditation, yoga, and stress self-regulation).
study_duration: 7 weeks, with follow-up assessments at 1 month and 6 months post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify the relationship between trait mindfulness and substance use behaviors and examine how this relationship varies across mindfulness facets, substance types, sample characteristics, and substance use severity.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found a small but significant negative relationship between trait mindfulness and substance use behaviors (r=-0.13), with stronger associations for alcohol and tobacco use, problematic substance use, and inpatient samples. Specific mindfulness facets (acting with awareness, non-judgment, non-reactivity) showed consistent associations with substance use behaviors.
population_specificity: Individuals with varying substance use behaviors, including clinical (inpatient/outpatient) and non-clinical samples.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of various spiritual interventions, with a focus on mindfulness, in improving job satisfaction and related outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness was the most widely used intervention, with promising outcomes in stress, burnout, mindfulness, and self-compassion. Future research should focus on longitudinal reinforcement of mindfulness.
population_specificity: Not specified (general context of job satisfaction and spiritual interventions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore whether mindfulness-based approaches could improve sleep in individuals with psychophysiological insomnia, particularly for those not responding to cognitive behavioral therapies.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that mindfulness-based approaches are effective in reducing stress and discomfort associated with insomnia and may help improve sleep through specific action mechanisms, based on a review of recent studies.
population_specificity: Individuals with psychophysiological insomnia, including those unresponsive to cognitive behavioral therapies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT) as an intervention for cancer patients, building upon existing Mindfulness-based approaches to improve psychological adjustment and coping.
results_summary: The study found that ACT shows promise for clinical- and cost-effectiveness in cancer patients, including those with psychological comorbidity, and may offer a more individualized framework for adjustment compared to traditional interventions. However, only a small number of studies have specifically examined ACT in this context, providing preliminary but not conclusive evidence.
population_specificity: Cancer patients, including those with psychological comorbidity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the similarities and differences between ACT processes and Buddhist tenets, and to report on a pilot ACT intervention for the Cambodian community in Toronto.
results_summary: ACT appears consistent with some core Buddhist tenets in alleviating suffering, with differences in scope reflecting their distinct aims. The pilot intervention suggested potential benefits of integrating psychological and spiritual perspectives for diverse populations.
population_specificity: Cambodian community in Toronto, in partnership with a Buddhist Holy Monk.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the impact of Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) versus non-MBCT group therapy on reducing non-mental health care utilization among high utilizers of primary care.
results_summary: MBCT significantly reduced non-mental health care utilization among high utilizers compared to non-MBCT group therapy, with an estimated reduction of 1 non-mental health visit for every two MBCT patients treated. The study suggests MBCT may help reduce distress-related high health care utilization.
population_specificity: High utilizers of primary care in Ontario, Canada, stratified by high/low rates of primary care utilization.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a comprehensive Mind-Body Medicine (MBM) program could improve flourishing, mindfulness, sense of coherence, and quality of life in patients with various diagnoses.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in psychological health, flourishing, mindfulness, and coherence, with correlations between these measures. The MBM program enhanced disease coping and quality of life.
population_specificity: 48 patients with various diagnoses in an outpatient clinic setting.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the feasibility, acceptability, preliminary efficacy, and mechanism of behavioral change of a smartphone-delivered ACT application (SmartQuit) for smoking cessation compared to a standard guideline-based application (QuitGuide).
results_summary: SmartQuit showed higher engagement (37.2 vs. 15.2 app opens) and promising quit rates (13% vs. 8%) compared to QuitGuide, particularly among participants with low baseline acceptance of cravings (15% vs. 8%). The results suggest ACT delivered via smartphone may be more effective than standard approaches, though the pilot design limits conclusions.
population_specificity: Adult smokers recruited nationally (n=196).

study_goal: To examine the effects of Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) on depression, anxiety, stress, and mindfulness in Korean nursing students.
results_summary: MBSR participants showed significantly greater reductions in depression, anxiety, and stress, along with increased mindfulness compared to the wait-list control group. The intervention demonstrated clinically meaningful improvements in mental health outcomes.
population_specificity: Nursing students at KN University College of Nursing in South Korea (n=44).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) is a viable method for managing stress by analyzing studies from 2009 to 2014.
results_summary: Of the 17 studies reviewed, 16 showed positive changes in psychological or physiological outcomes related to anxiety and/or stress, indicating MBSR is a promising modality for stress management despite some study limitations.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population with stress-related concerns).
effective_dosage: 8-week training program (combining mindfulness meditation and yoga).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantitatively assess the relationship between psychological flexibility (measured by AAQ/AAQ-II) and anxiety, and compare the effectiveness of ACT to other treatments like CBT for anxiety and OCD spectrum disorders.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found significant positive relationships between psychological flexibility and anxiety measures, and preliminary results showed ACT to be equally effective as manualized treatments like CBT. Data on mediation and moderation within ACT were also reviewed.
population_specificity: Individuals with anxiety disorders and OCD spectrum disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety, feasibility, and effects of an 8-week mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) course in adults with migraines.
results_summary: MBSR was safe with no adverse events and showed beneficial effects on headache duration, disability, self-efficacy, and mindfulness, though changes in migraine frequency and severity were not statistically significant due to the small sample size.
population_specificity: Adults with episodic migraines.
effective_dosage: Daily meditation average: 34 ± 11 minutes (range 16-50 minutes/day); median class attendance: 8 out of 9 sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to propose a multi-level metacognitive model of mindfulness and explore its relationship with metacognition components and development through practice.
results_summary: The study suggests mindfulness is linked to high-level metacognition, involves dynamic cooperation of metacognitive components, and develops with continuous practice. The model aligns with empirical data and theoretical approaches, offering avenues for future research.
population_specificity: Not specified (theoretical model, no specific population studied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of various interventions, including mindfulness training, in reducing burnout among medical students and residents.
results_summary: The study found mixed results regarding the effectiveness of mindfulness training in reducing burnout, with some studies showing benefit and others not. Other interventions like self-development groups and relaxation methods appeared more consistently effective.
population_specificity: Medical students and residents.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the relevance of the incentive sensitization theory for Gambling Disorder and explore its potential contributions to understanding behavioral addiction and treatment.
results_summary: The study did not directly assess Mindfulness but suggested that the incentive sensitization theory could provide insights into behavioral addictions like Gambling Disorder and open new treatment avenues.
population_specificity: Not specified (abstract focuses on theoretical application to Gambling Disorder).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of mindfulness-meditation as a non-pharmacological therapeutic strategy to enhance cognitive and brain reserve in multiple sclerosis (MS) patients.
results_summary: The study suggests that mindfulness-meditation may help cultivate cognitive reserve and protect against cognitive decline in MS, though more systematic research is needed to confirm its efficacy.
population_specificity: Multiple sclerosis (MS) patients with cognitive impairment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mindfulness-based therapies among other treatments for pediatric amplified pain syndromes.
results_summary: Preliminary evidence supports mindfulness-based therapies as a potential treatment for pediatric amplified pain syndromes, though the strongest evidence is for exercise-based and cognitive-behavioral treatments, especially in multidisciplinary formats.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients with chronic pain (amplified pain syndromes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review fMRI studies on GAD patients to evaluate if they support cognitive models, including the effects of mindfulness as a treatment.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness was one of the treatments evaluated in 4 studies, but specific results regarding its efficacy were not detailed. Emotion dysregulation in GAD was linked to PFC and ACC hypofunction.
population_specificity: Patients with Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the relative contributions of mindfulness practice time and practice quality in predicting psychological functioning and smoking abstinence outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness practice quality predicted improvements in psychological functioning at both posttreatment and follow-up, while practice time only predicted outcomes at posttreatment. Neither practice time nor quality predicted smoking abstinence at 1 or 6 months postquit.
population_specificity: Smokers participating in a mindfulness training program for smoking cessation and relapse prevention.
effective_dosage: 10 group meetings over 8 weeks (specific time per session not detailed).
study_duration: 8 weeks (with follow-up assessments at posttreatment and 5 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if mindfulness meditation (via the MAPs program) improves sleep quality more effectively than sleep hygiene education in older adults with prodromal sleep disturbances.
results_summary: The abstract does not report results, as it describes the study design and methodology of an ongoing RCT comparing MAPs to sleep hygiene education for sleep quality improvement.
population_specificity: Older adults with prodromal sleep disturbances from the urban Los Angeles community.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a workplace mindfulness program was practical and effective in reducing employee stress while improving resiliency and well-being.
results_summary: The mindfulness intervention group showed significant reductions in perceived stress and notable increases in mindfulness, resiliency, and vigor compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Employees from The Dow Chemical Company (n=89).
study_duration: Pre- and post-intervention, with a 6-month follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mindfulness meditation for improving attention in individuals with traumatic brain injury.
results_summary: The study found insufficient evidence to support mindfulness meditation for improving attention in traumatic brain injury patients. It was not recommended as an effective intervention for attentional problems in this population.
population_specificity: Individuals with traumatic brain injury experiencing attentional deficits.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review various meditation techniques, including mindfulness, and their potential benefits for children, adolescents, and their families.
results_summary: The study suggests that mindfulness and meditation techniques may help reduce symptomatic anxiety, depression, and pain in youth, though current data is not conclusive. Clinicians are advised to receive proper training before using these techniques.
population_specificity: Children, adolescents, and their families

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a single session of mindfulness could reduce postevent processing (PEP) and improve affect in individuals with social anxiety disorder (SAD).
results_summary: Mindfulness significantly reduced PEP and improved affect compared to the control condition, with no significant difference between mindfulness and cognitive restructuring. Decreases in cost biases and maladaptive beliefs predicted reductions in PEP.
population_specificity: Fifty-six individuals with social anxiety disorder (SAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of a mindfulness-based smoking cessation treatment against a standard control program (Freedom From Smoking) in achieving long-term abstinence.
results_summary: No significant difference was found in 6-month smoking abstinence rates between mindfulness (25.0%) and control (17.9%) groups (p=0.35). However, the mindfulness intervention showed positive effects on urges, mindfulness levels, perceived stress, and experiential avoidance.
population_specificity: 175 low socioeconomic status smokers in a midwestern city (2011-2012).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a brief mindfulness meditation intervention could reduce negative affect, lower urges to drink, and delay the next alcoholic drink in at-risk college student drinkers.
results_summary: The mindfulness intervention increased state mindfulness and relaxation while reducing negative affect immediately after the intervention, but it did not influence responses to negative affect induction or other outcome variables afterward. The initial gains were not maintained, possibly due to the intervention's brevity.
population_specificity: At-risk college student drinkers (N = 207)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether eight weeks of Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) improves visual discrimination ability and sustained attention compared to an active control (HEP) in a non-clinical population.
results_summary: The study found no significant improvement in sustained attention from MBSR compared to HEP, though there was some evidence of improved visual discrimination. The primary prediction on attentional fatigue was significant but uninterpretable.
population_specificity: Non-clinical community participants typical of MBSR participants (n=63, randomized to MBSR or HEP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate objective physiological markers (EEG and respiration signals) to distinguish meditation from control conditions in novice meditators.
results_summary: The study found differences in EEG frequency bands between meditation and control conditions and developed a classifier combining EEG and respiration signals with 85% accuracy, outperforming EEG-only classification (78%).
population_specificity: Older individuals with high stress levels (34 novice meditators).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR(BC)) on objective and subjective sleep parameters in breast cancer survivors.
results_summary: MBSR(BC) showed significant improvements in objective sleep parameters (sleep efficiency, percent sleep time, and fewer waking bouts) at 12 weeks, with small nonsignificant improvements in subjective sleep parameters. No significant relationship was found between practice duration and sleep outcomes.
population_specificity: Breast cancer survivors (stages 0-III), mean age 57 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Iyengar yoga, as a complementary therapy to cognitive-behavioral therapy, improves smoking cessation outcomes by enhancing mindfulness and cognitive deliberation.
results_summary: The study design suggests rigorous testing of yoga's efficacy compared to a control condition, with planned assessments of prolonged abstinence and mechanisms of action, but final results are not yet reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: Smokers attempting to quit.
study_duration: 8-week program with follow-ups at 3, 6, and 12 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the relationship between mindfulness and self-compassion in health care workers and assess its potential to reduce stress and improve compassionate patient care.
results_summary: The study suggests that mindfulness interventions, especially those incorporating lovingkindness, may increase self-compassion among health care workers, potentially reducing perceived stress and enhancing clinical care effectiveness.
population_specificity: Health care professionals

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of a classroom-based, teacher-implemented mindfulness meditation intervention on mental health and affect in middle school children.
results_summary: Both the mindfulness meditation group and the active control group showed significant improvements in clinical syndrome subscales and affect, with no significant difference between groups. However, the mindfulness group was significantly less likely to develop suicidal ideation or thoughts of self-harm compared to controls.
population_specificity: 101 healthy sixth-grade students (55 boys, 46 girls).
effective_dosage: Daily mindfulness meditation practice (specific duration not detailed).
study_duration: Not explicitly stated in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the development and empirical findings of psychological therapies, including mindfulness-based approaches, for auditory hallucinations (hearing voices).
results_summary: The review found that psychological therapies, including mindfulness-based approaches, are broadly effective for people with positive symptoms like auditory hallucinations, but more research is needed to understand their specific application to voices. Recent developments highlight the role of mindfulness in addressing connections between voices and self-identity, relationships, and personal history.
population_specificity: Individuals experiencing auditory hallucinations (hearing voices), particularly those with positive symptoms, potentially including schizophrenia and other populations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between impulsivity (specifically poor inhibitory control) and treatment outcomes in substance misuse, and whether increased awareness and acceptance of thoughts and emotions (mindfulness) improved outcomes.
results_summary: Impulsivity predicted poorer treatment outcomes (higher drug use severity), while increases in awareness and acceptance during treatment were associated with better outcomes, though this improvement was not linked to baseline impulsivity levels.
population_specificity: 144 adult substance users receiving treatment in a residential therapeutic community.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether Mindfulness-Oriented Recovery Enhancement could disrupt the risk chain linking chronic pain to prescription opioid misuse.
results_summary: The study suggests that Mindfulness-Oriented Recovery Enhancement can effectively target cognitive, affective, and psychophysiological mechanisms in chronic pain, potentially reducing the risk of opioid misuse. Evidence indicates this intervention may serve as a viable non-opioid treatment option.
population_specificity: Chronic pain patients at risk of prescription opioid misuse.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT) with support to taper/discontinue antidepressants (MBCT-TS) is superior to maintenance antidepressants (m-ADM) in preventing depressive relapse/recurrence and improving secondary outcomes like quality of life and cost-effectiveness.
results_summary: The study suggests MBCT-TS shows potential as an alternative to m-ADM for preventing depressive relapse/recurrence over 24 months, with additional benefits in secondary outcomes. The process studies aim to identify effective components of MBCT to improve therapy and inform theory.
population_specificity: Patients with recurrent major depressive disorder in full or partial remission, recruited through primary care.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if the benefits of mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT) on emotional distress in people with diabetes would be sustained six months after the intervention.
results_summary: MBCT showed sustained reductions in perceived stress, anxiety, and depressive symptoms (HADS) at six-month follow-up, but no significant effects on diabetes distress or HbA1c. The effects were statistically significant with moderate to large effect sizes, though POMS depressive symptoms did not remain significant after multiple testing correction.
population_specificity: 139 outpatients with diabetes (type-I or type-II) and lowered emotional well-being.
study_duration: Not specified (follow-up was six months post-intervention)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the working mechanisms and potential barriers of Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) in frequent primary care attendees with persistent medically unexplained symptoms (MUS).
results_summary: MBCT initiated a process of change involving increased awareness and acceptance of symptoms, emotions, and thoughts, leading to improved self-care and self-compassion. Barriers included social problems and resistance to symptom acceptance.
population_specificity: Top 10% frequent primary care attendees with persistent medically unexplained symptoms (MUS).
study_duration: MBCT course duration not specified, but follow-up was conducted 12 months later.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether MBSR is an effective and cost-effective treatment for chronic back pain, comparing it to CBT and usual care, while exploring psychosocial mediators.
results_summary: The study found that MBSR could be a valuable treatment option for chronic back pain, particularly for patients with significant psychosocial contributors, though direct efficacy results were pending trial completion.
population_specificity: 397 adults with nonspecific chronic back pain
effective_dosage: Eight weekly 2-hour group sessions (MBSR included an optional 6-hour retreat)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of internet-based cognitive behavior therapy (ICBT) incorporating mindfulness exercises with treatment-as-usual (TAU) for reducing depressive symptoms in primary care patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in depressive symptom reduction between ICBT (including mindfulness exercises) and TAU after 3 months, with 56% of ICBT participants completing all modules.
population_specificity: Adults aged ≥18 with mild to moderate depression in primary care settings in Sweden.
effective_dosage: Not specified (workbook, CD with mindfulness exercises, and 12-week online program).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a mindfulness-based psychological intervention in improving pain, physical function, and psychological wellbeing in patients undergoing total joint arthroplasty.
results_summary: The study design suggests potential benefits of mindfulness training for pain and functional outcomes post-surgery, but specific results are not detailed in the abstract. Secondary outcomes include psychological wellbeing and cost-effectiveness, indicating a comprehensive evaluation.
population_specificity: Adults with end-stage arthritis awaiting total hip or knee arthroplasty.
effective_dosage: Weekly group-based mindfulness classes (2.5 hours for 8 weeks) plus a 7-hour Saturday session in Week 6.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of individual mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT) and cognitive behavior therapy (CBT) versus a waiting-list control for reducing depressive symptoms in adults with type 1 or type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Both MBCT and CBT significantly reduced depressive symptoms compared to the waiting-list control, with clinically relevant improvements (26% and 29% vs. 4%). The interventions also improved anxiety, well-being, and diabetes-related distress but had no significant effect on HbA1c levels.
population_specificity: Adults with type 1 or type 2 diabetes and comorbid depressive symptoms (BDI-II ≥14).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and short-term efficacy of a mindfulness-based intervention in reducing eating disorder risk factors in young women with body image concerns.
results_summary: The mindfulness intervention showed statistically significant improvements in weight/shape concern, dietary restraint, thin ideal internalization, eating disorder symptoms, and psychosocial impairment post-intervention, but these gains were largely lost at follow-up. The dissonance-based intervention did not show significant improvements despite small to moderate effect sizes.
population_specificity: Young adult women with body image concerns (mean age 20.57, SD 3.22).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore mechanisms (psychological flexibility, mindfulness, emotion regulation) through which yoga might reduce PTSD symptoms compared to an assessment control.
results_summary: Yoga reduced expressive suppression and improved PTSD symptoms by increasing psychological flexibility, though psychological flexibility increased more in the control group. The association between increased psychological flexibility and reduced PTSD symptoms was significant only for the yoga group.
population_specificity: 38 women with DSM-IV full or subthreshold PTSD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether mindfulness-based interventions (MBI) could delay or prevent the transition from mild cognitive impairment (MCI) to Alzheimer's disease (AD) by addressing adverse factors like stress, depression, and metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: The study suggests that MBI may help manage stress, depressive symptoms, and inflammation, potentially slowing MCI/AD progression. Mechanisms include regulation of glucocorticosteroids, inflammation, and serotonin, as well as metabolic syndrome resolution.
population_specificity: Individuals with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) at risk of developing Alzheimer's disease (AD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the accessibility and implementation barriers of Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) in the UK and develop a plan to improve its equitable availability.
results_summary: The study found that MBCT is a cost-effective intervention for recurrent depression but faces uneven implementation across the UK. It seeks to identify barriers and facilitators to improve MBCT's adoption within the NHS.
population_specificity: Stakeholders involved in commissioning, managing, and implementing MBCT services in the UK.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of mindfulness meditation as the primary intervention for reducing binge eating, emotional eating, and weight change.
results_summary: Mindfulness meditation effectively decreased binge eating and emotional eating in populations engaging in these behaviors, but evidence for its effect on weight was mixed.
population_specificity: Individuals engaging in binge eating or emotional eating behaviors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of early specific cognitive-behavioural psychotherapy (CBT) with elements of mindfulness-based therapy (MBT) in adolescents and young adults at high risk for bipolar disorder.
results_summary: The study compared structured CBT with MBT elements to unstructured group meetings, measuring psychosocial functioning and affective symptomatology. Results indicated improvements in these endpoints, though specific outcomes for mindfulness alone were not detailed.
population_specificity: Adolescents and young adults (15-30 years old) at high risk for bipolar disorder, with specified affective symptomatology, reduced psychosocial functioning, and family history of (schizo)affective disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy, acceptability, and feasibility of dialectical behavior therapy (DBT) group skills training adapted for college students with ADHD.
results_summary: Participants receiving DBT group skills training showed higher treatment response and clinical recovery rates on ADHD symptoms and executive functioning, as well as greater improvements in quality of life compared to those receiving skills handouts.
population_specificity: College students (undergraduates) aged 18-24 with ADHD.
effective_dosage: Not specified (group skills training over 8 weeks).
study_duration: 8-week intervention phase with assessments at baseline, post-treatment, and 3-month follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether Mindfulness-Oriented Recovery Enhancement (MORE) could effectively target the cycle of chronic pain and prescription opioid misuse by integrating mindfulness training, cognitive-behavioral therapy, and positive psychology.
results_summary: The study reviewed clinical outcomes and neurocognitive mechanisms of MORE, suggesting it may help interrupt the risk chain linking chronic pain and prescription opioid misuse. Future research directions were discussed to further explore its clinical and pharmacologic applications.
population_specificity: Chronic pain patients with prescription opioid misuse or addiction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether mindfulness training could improve resilience mechanisms in active-duty Marines preparing for deployment.
results_summary: Marines who received mindfulness training showed improved stress reactivity and recovery, lower plasma neuropeptide Y concentration after stress, and attenuated brain activation in stress-related regions.
population_specificity: Active-duty Marine infantry platoons (N=281)
effective_dosage: 20 hours of classroom instruction plus daily homework exercises over 8 weeks

study_goal: The researchers sought to determine whether mindfulness meditation acutely lowers blood pressure in hypertensive African-American males with chronic kidney disease and whether these effects are mediated by reduced sympathetic nerve activity.
results_summary: Mindfulness meditation significantly reduced systolic BP, diastolic BP, mean arterial pressure, heart rate, and muscle sympathetic nerve activity compared to the control intervention. Controlled breathing alone did not replicate these effects, suggesting meditation’s benefits are not solely due to reduced respiratory rate.
population_specificity: Hypertensive African-American males with chronic kidney disease.

study_goal: To examine the effects of a mindfulness-based psychoeducation programme on psychiatric symptoms, psychosocial functioning, insight, and hospital readmissions in Chinese people with schizophrenia.
results_summary: The mindfulness-based psychoeducation group showed significantly greater improvements in psychiatric symptoms, psychosocial functioning, insight, and reduced duration of hospital readmissions compared to conventional psychoeducation and routine care groups over 24 months.
population_specificity: Chinese outpatients with schizophrenia (n=107).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the feasibility and impact of an online synchronous Mindfulness-Based Cancer Recovery (MBCR) program for distressed cancer survivors without access to in-person MBCR.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in mood disturbance, stress symptoms, spirituality, and mindful awareness in the online MBCR group compared to controls, with moderate effect sizes. Feasibility targets for recruitment and retention were met, and participants reported high satisfaction.
population_specificity: Underserved distressed cancer survivors (62 men and women) within 3 years of completing primary cancer treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the effectiveness of mindfulness-based therapy in improving sexual desire and arousal in women with low sexual functioning.
results_summary: Mindfulness-based group therapy significantly improved sexual desire, arousal, lubrication, satisfaction, and overall sexual functioning, while reducing sex-related distress, orgasmic difficulties, and depressive symptoms. Increases in mindfulness and reductions in depressive symptoms predicted improvements in sexual desire.
population_specificity: Women seeking treatment for low sexual desire and arousal (mean age ~40-42 years).
effective_dosage: Four 90-minute group sessions (mindfulness meditation, cognitive therapy, and education).
study_duration: 6-month follow-up period (intervention duration not explicitly stated beyond session count).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of an 8-week mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) training on clinical endpoints and cardiovascular risk factors in patients with type 2 diabetes and early diabetic kidney disease.
results_summary: After 1 year, the MBSR group showed reduced urinary albumin excretion, stress levels, catecholamine levels, improved blood pressure, and reduced intima media thickness, but these effects were not sustained after 2-3 years.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes and early diabetic kidney disease (n=110, randomized to intervention or control).
study_duration: 8 weeks (with follow-up assessments at 1, 2, and 3 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of Mindfulness-Oriented Recovery Enhancement (MORE) on biopsychosocial aspects of pain-related impairment in chronic pain patients.
results_summary: MORE participants showed significantly greater reductions in pain-related functional interference across multiple domains compared to a support group, with psychological effects being more durable than physiological ones at follow-up.
population_specificity: Chronic pain patients (N = 115; mean age 48 ± 14 years; 68% female).
effective_dosage: Eight weeks of MORE (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether brief mindfulness meditation training reduces psychological and neuroendocrine stress reactivity and whether pre-existing dispositional mindfulness moderates these effects.
results_summary: Brief mindfulness meditation reduced self-reported psychological stress reactivity but increased cortisol reactivity compared to cognitive training. Participants with low pre-existing mindfulness showed the greatest cortisol reactivity. No significant effects were observed for blood pressure.
population_specificity: Young adult volunteers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and optimize a low-tension intervention model combining mindfulness, small steps, and group support to promote stable, long-term lifestyle changes in overweight or obese individuals.
results_summary: The study described the iterative development of an attractive and manageable intervention model, now being tested in a randomized controlled trial, but did not provide specific efficacy results for mindfulness alone.
population_specificity: Overweight or obese citizens (groups of 20 participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of mindfulness-based interventions (MBIs) for individuals currently experiencing depressive or anxiety disorders.
results_summary: MBIs showed significant benefits for depressive symptom severity but not for anxiety symptom severity, particularly when compared to inactive controls. Effects were more pronounced for Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) than for Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR).
population_specificity: Individuals diagnosed with a current episode of depressive or anxiety disorders (n=578).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the acceptability and effectiveness of a six-week mindfulness intervention in individuals with diabetes mellitus and coronary heart disease, focusing on reducing worry and thought suppression.
results_summary: The intervention was highly acceptable, with 90% completing at least five sessions, and led to significant reductions in worry and thought suppression, improved sleep, greater relaxation, and more accepting approaches to illness.
population_specificity: Individuals with diabetes mellitus and coronary heart disease (n = 40).
effective_dosage: Not specified (six-week meditation and mindfulness intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how genetic variation influences individual differences in positive affect (PA) changes in response to mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT) in individuals with residual depressive symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that genetic variations in BDNF, CHRM2, DRD4, and OPRM1 genes moderated the impact of MBCT on PA, with CHRM2 and OPRM1 specifically affecting PA levels post-MBCT, suggesting genetic factors influence treatment response.
population_specificity: Individuals (n=126) with residual depressive symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) versus yoga on urinary urge incontinence (UI) at 8 weeks, 6 months, and 1 year after an 8-week program.
results_summary: MBSR showed greater median percent reduction in urinary urge incontinence episodes compared to yoga at all time points, with statistically significant improvements at 8 weeks. Participants in MBSR also reported better subjective improvement at 8 weeks and 1 year compared to yoga.
population_specificity: Women aged 18+ with urge-predominant incontinence and ≥5 UI episodes on a 3-day voiding diary, no recent anticholinergic use.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of an online cognitive behavioral therapy program incorporating mindfulness training for improving female sexual functioning and reducing distress.
results_summary: The treatment group showed significant improvements in sexual desire, arousal, orgasm, and distress, with some benefits maintained at three-month follow-up. Partner sexual functioning also improved, though sexual pain did not show significant change.
population_specificity: Women with female sexual problems and related distress, including difficulties with desire, arousal, orgasm, and pain.

study_goal: To determine the effectiveness of mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) and mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT) on psychological and physical outcomes for people with vascular disease.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in stress, depression, and anxiety, but effects on physical outcomes (e.g., blood pressure, albuminuria, stress hormones) were mixed. Psychological benefits were evident, but physical benefits were not conclusively established.
population_specificity: People with vascular disease, including those with prehypertension/hypertension, type 1 or 2 diabetes, heart disease, and stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Tai Chi Chuan (TCC) is an effective exercise for promoting physical and psychological wellbeing in college students.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a rigorous trial to evaluate TCC's effects on balance, flexibility, mental health, and other outcomes, but results are not yet reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: College students from Fujian University of Traditional Chinese Medicine.
effective_dosage: TCC training five days per week, one hour per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a multiple health behavior change intervention (CanChange) on psychosocial outcomes, including mindfulness, in colorectal cancer survivors.
results_summary: The intervention showed significant improvements in mindfulness at 6 months, along with other psychosocial outcomes and quality of life, with some effects persisting at 12 months.
population_specificity: Colorectal cancer survivors (n=410)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the effectiveness of Stepping Stones Triple P (SSTP) and Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT) in reducing behavioral problems in children with cerebral palsy (CP).
results_summary: SSTP combined with ACT significantly reduced behavioral problems, hyperactivity, and parental overreactivity, while SSTP alone also decreased behavioral and emotional symptoms. These improvements were maintained at the 6-month follow-up.
population_specificity: Parents (primarily mothers) of children with cerebral palsy (CP), with children aged 5.3 ± 3.0 years.
study_duration: Postintervention and 6-month follow-up (exact intervention duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effectiveness of yoga, particularly its mindfulness and meditation aspects, as an intervention for depression.
results_summary: The review found promising positive effects of yoga on depression, though the studies had methodological limitations that could inform future research.
population_specificity: General population, with noted vulnerability among women, young adults, and seniors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mindfulness-based interventions, alongside other approaches, in improving general well-being and supporting lifestyle changes among obese individuals with stress symptoms.
results_summary: The study compared mindfulness-based interventions (mobile-guided and face-to-face group) with other methods, measuring psychological well-being, lifestyle habits, and physical health. Results indicated potential benefits, but specific outcomes for mindfulness were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Obese individuals reporting stress symptoms (n=339).
study_duration: 10 weeks (post-intervention measurement), with follow-up at 36 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore how mindfulness-based cognitive hypnotherapy (MBCH) integrates mindfulness strategies with cognitive hypnotherapy to enhance emotional disorder treatment, particularly depression.
results_summary: The study suggests that MBCH, combining mindfulness, cognitive hypnotherapy, and heart-focused strategies, may catalyze healing for emotional disorders like depression by fostering psychophysiological coherence and psychological well-being.
population_specificity: Not specified (general clinical practice context implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 3-week self-compassion group intervention could enhance resilience and well-being among female college students compared to a control intervention.
results_summary: The self-compassion intervention significantly increased self-compassion, mindfulness, optimism, and self-efficacy while reducing rumination. Both interventions improved life satisfaction and connectedness, but no differences were found for worry and mood.
population_specificity: Female college students

study_goal: The researchers sought to identify patient characteristics linked to MBCT treatment response for headache pain and explore the processes of change that differentiated responders from non-responders.
results_summary: Responders showed significant improvements in pain acceptance and catastrophizing, with cognitive changes being a key theme. Both groups reported improved psychosocial outcomes and highlighted non-specific therapeutic factors, though barriers to mindfulness meditation were noted.
population_specificity: 21 participants with headache pain (14 responders, 7 non-responders).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of mindfulness-based meditation techniques as part of Lifestyle Medicine for depression prevention and management.
results_summary: The study suggests that mindfulness-based meditation techniques, alongside other lifestyle modifications, may contribute to mental wellbeing and potentially prevent or manage depression, though rigorous long-term research is needed.
population_specificity: General population, with a focus on depression prevention and management.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test whether mindfulness-based cognitive therapy could reduce stress, lessen psoriasis severity, improve quality of life, and reduce distress in people with psoriasis.
results_summary: The mindfulness group reported statistically significant improvements in psoriasis severity and quality of life but showed no significant differences in perceived stress or distress compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 29 people with psoriasis (ages 22-70; 16 females, 13 males).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the history, recent developments, and future directions of meditation research, particularly focusing on integrating contemplative traditions like the Nalanda approach with conventional scientific methods.
results_summary: The study highlights recent findings on meditation's mechanisms and effects, suggesting that the Nalanda tradition's framework may help interpret data and guide research. Two studies reviewed indicate that the Nalanda approach is as well received as familiar methods and may be more effective.
population_specificity: Not specified (general meditation research and contemplative traditions)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of a mindfulness-based training program in reducing burnout and mood disturbance while increasing empathy and mindfulness among primary health care professionals.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant improvements in mood disturbance, mindfulness, burnout, and empathy, with large to moderate effect sizes, while the control group exhibited no significant changes.
population_specificity: Primary health care professionals in Spain (68 participants, 43 in the intervention group and 25 in the control group).
effective_dosage: 8 sessions of 2.5 hours per week plus a 1-day session of 8 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term efficacy of Mindfulness-Based Relapse Prevention (MBRP) in reducing relapse compared to cognitive-behavioral relapse prevention (RP) and treatment as usual (TAU) over a 12-month follow-up period.
results_summary: MBRP and RP significantly reduced relapse risk and substance use compared to TAU at 6 months. At 12 months, MBRP showed added benefits over RP and TAU in reducing drug use and heavy drinking.
population_specificity: 286 individuals (71.5% male, 42.1% ethnic/racial minority) aged 18-70 who completed initial treatment for substance use disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of mindfulness-based interventions (MBIs) in treating obesity-related eating behaviours such as binge eating, emotional eating, and external eating.
results_summary: The review found that 86% of the included studies reported improvements in targeted eating behaviours, supporting the efficacy of MBIs for changing obesity-related eating behaviours. The interventions used various mindfulness approaches, including combined therapies and mindful eating programmes.
population_specificity: Individuals with obesity-related eating behaviours (e.g., binge eating, emotional eating, external eating).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of mindfulness eating and yoga exercise on blood sugar levels in pregnant Thai women with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM).
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant reductions in fasting plasma glucose, 2-h postprandial blood glucose, and HbA1c levels compared to controls (p<0.05). Mindfulness eating and yoga exercise demonstrated health benefits for glycemic control in this population.
population_specificity: Pregnant Thai women with GDM.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) is an effective augmentation to antidepressants for adults with treatment-resistant depression (TRD).
results_summary: The study compared MBCT to an active control (HEP) in adults with TRD, measuring changes in depression severity, treatment response, and remission. Results were assessed using clinician-rated and participant-rated scales, but specific outcomes are not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18+ with moderate to severe treatment-resistant depression (TRD) who failed to respond to at least two trials of antidepressants.
study_duration: Participants were followed for 1 year, with assessments at weeks 1-7, 8, 24, 36, and 52.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the nonjudgment component of mindfulness influences smoking cessation outcomes when comparing mindfulness training (MT) to a standard cognitive-behavioral treatment (FFS).
results_summary: Smokers with high baseline nonjudgment scores (>30.5) smoked significantly fewer cigarettes per day when randomized to MT (3.9 cigs/d) compared to FFS (11.1 cigs/d). Trait nonjudgment may help personalize treatment assignments for better outcomes.
population_specificity: 85 tobacco smokers in a randomized control trial.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Mindfulness Training for Smokers (MTS) versus usual care therapy (telephonic quit line and nicotine patches) for smoking cessation.
results_summary: Among treatment initiators, the MTS group showed significantly higher 6-month smoking abstinence rates (38.7%) compared to the control group (20.6%, p = .05), suggesting MTS may be more effective for smoking cessation.
population_specificity: Low socioeconomic status smokers in Madison, Wisconsin (196 participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review theoretical models and mechanisms of mindfulness in addiction treatment and evaluate mindfulness-based relapse prevention (MBRP).
results_summary: The study suggests mindfulness practices are effective in treating addiction, including substance use disorders and behavioral addictions like gambling, and provides an overview of MBRP's session content, treatment targets, and participant feedback. Future research directions include refining operationalization, identifying moderators, and adapting protocols for specific populations.
population_specificity: Individuals with substance use disorders and behavioral addictions (e.g., gambling).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of mindfulness-based relapse prevention (MBRP) versus standard relapse prevention (RP) in reducing drug use and related problems among women referred by the criminal-justice system.
results_summary: At 15-week follow-up, women in the MBRP group reported significantly fewer drug use days and fewer legal and medical problems compared to the RP group. The study suggests MBRP may be more effective than standard RP for this population.
population_specificity: Women referred by the criminal-justice system participating in a residential addictions treatment program.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of MBCT in reducing depressive relapse/recurrence over 2 years in a pragmatic study design, including its suitability when combined with medication.
results_summary: MBCT participants had fewer days with major depression (65 vs. 112 in controls) and lower relapse rates in both years. Subgroup analyses showed MBCT was particularly effective for those in specialist care or taking antidepressants/mood stabilizers.
population_specificity: Non-depressed adults with a history of three or more depressive episodes.
interactions: Works well combined with antidepressants/mood stabilizers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of mindfulness meditation in group versus individual settings on weight loss, cognitive-behavioral avoidance, impulsivity, and mindfulness.
results_summary: Group mindfulness meditation led to weight loss and reduced cognitive-behavioral avoidance, while individual meditation resulted in less weight loss, increased avoidance, and higher mindfulness scores, with decreased impulsivity.
population_specificity: Adults trying to lose weight (n=170).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of an acceptance and mindfulness-based stress management workshop in reducing psychological distress and improving well-being among support staff working with individuals with intellectual disability and challenging behavior.
results_summary: The intervention significantly reduced psychological distress in the intervention group compared to the control group, with effects largely maintained at 6-week follow-up. Thought suppression also decreased significantly in the intervention group, though no significant changes were observed in well-being or experiential avoidance/psychological inflexibility.
population_specificity: Support staff working with individuals with intellectual disability and challenging behavior (n=120).
